text: CLOSE on a CANDLE, its base ringed by dripped wax. It’s perched on the sill of a small window, bathed in grayish, early morning light. A SNUFFER enters the frame and extinguishes the flame. We PULL BACK to see the MAIDSERVANT who has just put out candle, moving onto the next candle in the long corridor, snuffing it out as well. And onto the next when she HEARS The ECHO of footfalls and clanking swords. As THREE MEN r the corner she steps back, head bowed, making room for th Walking briskly toward us are THOMAS ANDREWS (Sheriff of Northamptonshire) flanked by two Earls - SHREWSBURY and K They pass by the Maidservant without acknowledging her. S watches them go as they round another corner. Andrews and his men arrive at a small door. A GUARD await them. Upon their arrival the Guard fetches a set of keys his belt...
Establishing - a foreboding, turreted castle rising from marshland of an adjacent river, surrounded by a moat. We the UNLOCKING OF A BOLT as we CUT TO--

MARY STUART - Queen of Scots, Dowager Queen of France. But we see her from BEHIND - her back to us. And this is where we shall stay for now. Seeing events as she does, following from just a few feet to the rear. She is on her knees in prayer, joined by her CHAMBERMAIDS an OLDER MARY SETON (the younger version of whom we shall introduce soon), facing a small window which overlooks th landscape we just saw. As the heavy door pivots open, revealing Andrews, she remains in prayer, her back to him He bows his head, then, with solemnity and respect--

It’s time. Mary stands, as do her Servants. She’s wearing a long, bl satin gown. A white cap and laced veil against which her dark, auburn hair is lustrous. It’s her hair that we’re d to - since we’ve yet to see her face. She goes to a side table and retrieves two carefully cho items, an ivory crucifix in one hand, a Latin prayer book the other. Meanwhile one of the Maidservants loops a string of rosar beads with a golden cross to a girdle at her waist. Anoth fastens a gold chain around her neck, from which hangs a medallion bearing the image of Christ as the Lamb of God.
From behind. Mary is being led across by the Earls and Guards. She pauses to look up at the sky. The last time s will feel the sun directly on her face.
Your grace. She resumes following her escort, who have paused for her
QUEEN ELIZABETH - from behind - walking alone, slowly, as in a daze. She looks up at the sky, then lowers her head. begins to sob. We can’t see her tears, but we can see her body shaking.

Your grace. We shift focus to WILLIAM CECIL on the far side of the courtyard. He is her most trusted advisor on the Privy Council - a persuasive, manipulative man who understands realpolitik of power and wields it well. From behind him, see Elizabeth quickly dry her tears.

We’re above and behind as Mary strides through a large se doors, her Ladies, Andrews and Guards in tow. Down the hall a little SERVANT GIRL peeks around the corn to get a glimpse. The MAIDSERVANT from the first scene gr her by the wrist and pulls her out of view. Mary rounds the corner, taking us to--

A vast room filled with a hundred SPECTATORS. At the far of the room is a WOODEN STAGE. The crowd parts. She heads directly for the stage, mounts steps to the platform where two MEN stand waiting for her  Still behind her, from over her shoulder, we can see the crowd staring up, a hundred solemn faces - the KNIGHTS an GENTLEMEN OF NORTHAMPTONSHIRE. There is a low murmuring a number of men speak in hushed tones to each other. It’s worth noting that this crowd is ALL MEN. The only wo in attendance are Old Seton and Mary’s two Ladies. Mary’s back and the POV beyond fills the frame, but off- screen we hear three KNOCKS of a cane on the wooden platf to call the room to attention. A slight, barely noticeabl flinch from each knock as the room silences. The Clerk of Elizabeth's Privy Council, ROBERT BEALE - re aloud off-screen. We only hear his voice--

By order of our sovereign Elizabeth, Queen of England, Wales and Ireland, Overlord of Scotland, certified by her Privy Council and Parliament, Mary Stuart is condemned to death this day, the eighth of February, the year of our Lord one thousand five hundred eighty-seven... During which we CUT from face to face of Nobles in the audience, all staring up at Mary in morbid fascination an anxiousness. We are in Mary’s POV now.
On Elizabeth’s back as a Guard opens the chamber door. Th COUNCIL stands and bows as she takes her seat. With a sli gesture she instructs them to sit. Cecil steps forward.
For your fellow Princes on the continent - that they might know... He places a letter before her. She glances over it. An ATTENDANT brings her a quill and ink. She looks back up.
We will not ask God’s forgiveness for that which is just.

We are still behind Mary. She stands. Two Earls remove he outer garment - the black satin - revealing a crimson gar beneath. The colour of martyrdom. A collective gasp. We CUT TO Noblemen in the midst of the crowd, gazing at h with disgust. One whispers to the other--
She thinks herself a martyr.
Wretched woman. BACK TO Mary. She turns to the Executioner - BULL. We rem on her back. Bull bows his head in supplication--
I plead your forgiveness.
I forgive you with all my heart. You shall make an end of all my troubles. Bull gestures to a cushion before her in front of the blo As Mary kneels down she begins to recite a psalm in Latin

Salve, Regina, Mater misericordie, vita, dulcedo, et spes nostra, salve. Ad te clamamus exsules filii Heve, In te Domino confido... As she repeats the prayer the camera COMES AROUND to face Mary for the FIRST TIME. As we do, we hear a SURGE of surf on a shore, and once we land upon her face, we are no longer in Fotheringhay Castle... It is 27 YEARS PRIOR and we are at--

Mary kneeling on the sand in prayer. The water is surging soaking her dress. She shivers from the cold but continue her prayer. The moment has the same solemnity as the execution sequen but the daylight and anticipation and Mary’s youth also charge it with the excitement and danger of a new beginni As the surf retreats she leans down and kisses the sand - first time she’s touched Scottish soil since she was a gi Behind her we can see her ship anchored in the distance. Several rowboats have been pulled up onto the shore - tru and other goods being unloaded by sailors. A distressed look on Mary’s ashen face while she’s still down, her face inches above the sand. She retches. Four w quickly come to her aid.  They are the “Four Marys” - BEATON, SETON, FLEMING and LIVINGSTON - Mary’s ladies-in-waiting and closest friends hear concerned chatter among them as they attend to their mistress.

C’est fini. (It’s passed.) --which silences them. Mary cups her hand in the salt wat and brings it up to her mouth to wash her face clean. Set hands her a handkerchief. Mary dries her face then stands Horses are making their way onto the shore. On BOTHWELL - Scottish Lord and the Queen’s Champion. He has the harden bearing of a soldier accented by the flash of an adventur He looks down the shore and sees figures in the distance PEASANTS cockle-picking. Near them is a small wagon with Clydesdale pony.

We're further down the shore with the PEASANT FAMILY now: They include an OLDER MAN, TWO TEENAGE SONS and a LITTLE - his daughter. Bothwell is paying the OLDER MAN several coins as GUARDS emptying the wagon of cockles, dumping them on a pile in sand. Mary is nearby on foot beside her horse. Mary looks at the old Peasant. A hard, poor life is evide by the deep wrinkles in his face, a mouth turned inward b lost teeth. Then she looks to his DAUGHTER - in a dirty muddy burlap frock - who does not bow. She’s only five years old, the age Mary was when she fled to France. CUT TO the Nobleman helping the Four Marys into the peasa wagon. Livingston holds a handkerchief to her nose, put o by the fishy smell. The other three seem no less disguste BACK TO Mary as Bothwell helps her onto her horse. Legs astride, not side saddle. Once atop, she looks regal. Bothwell mounts his horse and leads the small entourage forward. The little girl runs to keep up with it. Her father yells to her but she ignores him, running alongside Mary’s hors Mary and the little girl lock eyes. She sees a curious an defiant fire in the girl’s expression which aligns with h own curious and defiant flame. Mary smiles at the girl. She smiles back, then stops. Mar turns her eyes forward again, as if staring into her futu  Bothwell turns to her, in French--
Tout cela correspond a4 vos souvenirs? (Is it how you remember it?)
Je m’en souviens a4 peine. (I scarcely remember it at all.)

In stark contrast to the rawness of the Scottish countrys we're in an opulent, formal chamber. RANDOLPH - the Engli Ambassador to Scotland - stands before Elizabeth. Cecil i off to her side. Dudley is to the other side, along with other LORDS. Elizabeth’s ladies sit on stools and pillows near her feet.
Her protector is Lord Bothwell, an able soldier.
So she comes readied for war.
She may well depart once married. But I cannot profess to know her purpose.
What says her brother?
Moray is only her half-brother, Madam. I believe his allegiance is fully with us.
What proof?
He pledges to protect the Church of Scotland.
And yet he has no power to make such a pledge if he is no longer Regent.
The Nobles respect him.
But can he control her?
(directed at Cecil) If she is like our Queen, she does not yield to a bridle. Giggles from the Ladies. Even Elizabeth is amused.
So says our Master of the Horse. More giggles from the ladies. Cecil doubles down--

(to Dudley) By bridle do you speak of mounts...? Dudley stiffens. This is a touchy subject to bring up ina public setting, but Cecil will not allow himself to be challenged by an inferior Lord. Then triples down--
.»..or do you speak of matrimony? Elizabeth holds up her hand to silence everyone. Cecil ha gone far enough. He gives her a slight nod. She waits a b for solemnity to return, then--
(to Randolph) You may tell Scotland that we wish to love the Stuarts as our kin, but they should love us in return.
Madam - if I may speak... All eyes on Cecil.
While she is on this island, she must bow to you, not to Rome. Our Catholics must know that a papist will never again sit on the English throne.
She has offered to recognise my rightful claim.
Only if you make her heir. We owe her no such consolation.
What would you suggest?
(to Randolph) Is it fair to say that Moray would rather remain Regent?
His discomfort would imply so.
(back to Elizabeth) Let his discomfort feed hers. Kill her hope. And hopeless she may return to the comfort of the continent. Cecil switches tones.

Of course, if you should offer love, perhaps your love will sway her. But I do not know what mortal would choose a Prince’s love over a Prince’s crown. It’s enough to convince her. She turns to Randolph--
Speak to her brother. Make our demands clear.
Recognition without recompense.
However you choose to convey it.
Aye, Madam - I shall go at once. During which Cecil shoots Dudley a look. This is how you bridle a Queen.

CLOSE on the EARL OF MORAY, Regent of Scotland and Mary’s half-brother. He is atop a small bridge with windows on either side as he watches Mary’s entourage approach benea The castle itself looms above them all. We can see a flurry of activity in the courtyard beyond SERVANTS darting through the courtyard in preparation for Queen’s arrival, hurriedly lighting torches. On his face see tenseness. He’d rather none of this were happening. Moray leaves the window to go and greet his sister. TIME CUT to the Courtyard. TIGHT on Mary’s outstretched h Then Moray’s face enters the frame and lightly kisses it. We PULL BACK to see Moray kneeling before her, removing h sword as he does so.
Mon frére... (My brother) He stands and she embraces him. Bothwell watches from sev yards away. He and Moray lock eyes - mutual distrust - as Moray and Mary embrace.

Mary, Moray and the Four Marys make their way through corridors and a series of chambers, some half-furnished a being decorated for the Queen, others still bare. Everyth feels a bit ad hoc and rushed. The servants bow as Mary passes. She soaks it in during the following exchange wit Moray - only vaguely familiar. On the whole she might as be laying eyes upon these rooms for the first time.
You must be tired.
I am quite well.
Supper is being prepared. We can have it brought to your chamber if you like.
Yes, thank you. A beat. Moray considers his next question, then asks it casually, though it’s far from a casual question--
How long will you be staying?
At Holyrood?
In Scotland.  10. She answers him just as casually, though like the questio itself, there’s nothing casual about it’s substance.
(with a smile) Are you already planning my departure?
Of course not. We’ve long awaited your return. Moray turns to a servant - KATE, elderly - who has been trailing behind them. MORAY (CONT’D) Kate will show you to your chambers.
This way, Madam. As Kate leads Mary and her Ladies down an adjacent hall, Moray’s smile fades. He turns to Bothwell.
Do you intend to stay as well?
I swore an oath to the Queen’s mother to protect her.
She is well protected here.
I shall uphold my oath just the same.
And what reward does your loyalty command?

I am driven by duty, not ambition. A scoffing and dismissive half-smirk from Moray. He doesn buy it for a moment. INT. HOLYROOD - QUEEN’S CHAMBER - NIGHT The room is lit by several candles, but still dim. It’s completely empty. Mary looks around, taking in the barene
We are having a bed brought from town.  10A. Mary points to a wall, addressing the Servant--
My mother’s was here?
Yes, Madam.  11. And with this the Servant’s voice breaks. She can’t stop tear from rolling down her cheek.
My apologies... Mary goes to her--
What is it?
Her Majesty was too young to recall... (puts a palm to her chest) ...but I was your wet nurse. You’re so beautiful. Like your mother. Mary offers her a warm, compassionate smile.

(embarrassed, to escape--) With permission - I will make certain the bed. Mary nods. Kate exits the chamber. Mary turns to the Four Marys, who are trying to hide their mortification at the gloomy environs.
A dire vrai, ce n’est pas une autre France. (It is no France.) She offers this as humour, and the Four Marys force a lau but it’s not very convincing. Then quite seriously--

Mais notre devoir n’est plus 4 la France. C’est ici qu’il nous améne. (But our duty is no longer to France. It is here.) The Four Marys stop smiling. It’s a solemn reminder that their lives are forever changed.

Mary is seated while an ARTIST paints a miniature portrai her. The Four Marys are overseeing ATTENDANTS who are in process of hanging tapestries on the walls. Mary is begin to make the place her own. Moray is with her.
Emperor Ferdinand looks to wed one of his sons...  12.
Are we to bow to the Hapsburgs?
They are a good family. Quite powerful.
And would require me to leave Scotland.
A small price for such a favorable union. She turns to him--
Favorable for whom? They lock eyes for a moment. On Moray, clenching his jaw. Mary notices something on the far side of the room beyond Moray. Stands--
Higher. And we see she’s referring to one of the tapestries being hung on the wall. The Attendants raise it a foot.
This one. Mary watches as the ATTENDANTS climb down from their ladd and move the tapestry over to the new wall. As they place ladders, they raise the tapestry--
Yes. Thank you. (to Moray) Better - is it not?
(stifling his annoyance) I know nothing of these matters. She takes his hand. Warmly--

You have done us a great service as ward over this realm. We would be wise to follow your example. Let us dispense with marriage for now and talk of governance. Those are matters which you know far better than myself. He forces a smile.
I appreciate your confidence in me. She glances back up at the tapestry, decisive.
Yes. Hang it here. She heads back over to sit before the Artist.
Continue.
Chin higher. We are TIGHT on the Artist’s POV as she tilts We CUT FROM this visage of her face to--
her chin up. Her portrait. A small one. Held in the light by BESS OF HARDWICK, Elizabeth’s lady in waiting.

What do you see Bess? We PULL BACK. Elizabeth is studying the miniature along w Bess as the other ladies in waiting make final adjustment Elizabeth’s appearance - placing rings on fingers, powder her face--
Charming. Fair - if the painter does not lie. Arrogant, perhaps. I do not like the look of her. (beat) And you?
Young. Clever. (beat) Confident. Looks down at her hand as a Lady places a ring upon it.
She would have no trouble securing a husband, even without her throne.
Nor would you, Madam. Elizabeth turns to her, eyes flashing--  14.
Forgive me...

COURTIERS are crammed into the room, waiting for Elizabet emerge. This is one of the few times of the day that they have direct access to the Queen. It’s all about jockeying position, being seen and seeing others. Among those in court are the EARL OF LENNOX and his hands 17 year-old son, HENRY DARNLEY, straining to get a prime near the door to the Queen’s chambers. As Lennox tries to edge his way forward--

(to Darnley) Come. Closer. We SHIFT TO right by the door to the Queen’s chambers whe we find Cecil and Dudley. They have a prime position beca they will escort her to the privy council chamber. They s in low tones so as not to be overheard.
She will not accept my hand.
You cannot be certain.
I know because I know her heart. The moment I betray it with ambition, I lose her heart.
Would you rather she lose her crown?
You exaggerate.

(growing impatient) How much blood has been spilled in Rome’s name? If a Catholic Queen bears a child before our own, have no doubt that blood will spill again. Muster your courage and save us from her reticence.
What you claim I lack in courage, you lack in reason, sir. She will not have me.  14~.
Nor would I have a commoner be king of England if we were not desperate for an heir. But we must mould the clay before us.
(insulted) I am no commoner.
Nor are you noble.  15.

Bess adjusts Elizabeth’s hair. Elizabeth holds out her ha and an attendant places a hand mirror in it. Elizabeth ho up the mirror and looks at her own reflection. We RACK FOCUS from the mirror to the portrait of Mary in background so that her blurred reflection and the portrai are side by side in the frame. Elizabeth lets her gaze li on the portrait for a moment, we RACK FOCUS back to the mirror as she looks at her face once again, then turns an presents herself to her ladies. With a matter-of-fact, discerning eye.
Aye.
We are with Cecil and Dudley again--
You should bring it up with her directly.
I have, many times.
Then there is your answer.

On all other matters she follows my counsel. I have her trust, but you have her affections. However much it pains me, I am not above admitting you wield a power I do not. You can succeed where I-- But before he can finish the sentence, the doors to the Queen’s Chamber open, revealing Elizabeth. The COURTIERS bow as they part to form a diagonal path ac the room. Elizabeth turns to Cecil and Dudley.
(to Cecil) Good morning, William.
Madam. She turns to Dudley, and saying it with far more warmth--
Robert.  15A.
(as warmly) Resplendent.  16. Elizabeth smiles.

Would you? He holds out his arm. She loops hers within his. They beg to walk along the path, Cecil falling in closely behind t with Bess and the Ladies. A bit of jostling among the Courtiers to be closest to th path. It’s not unseemly - they are Nobles and need to maintain their dignity - but it’s noticeable. As Elizabeth walks, she nods to some, ignores others. Len presses forward, Darnley following. As Elizabeth approach Lennox makes a show of a deep bow, but it goes intentiona unnoticed by Elizabeth. Lennox tries to recover by appealing to Cecil once Elizab has passed, stepping out in front of him. He keeps his vo low so as not to be overheard--
My Lord - I would ask our mistress to beseech Queen Mary that I be allowed to return to Scotland as Earl of our ancestral--
(the gall, full volume) This is not the place.
(insistent) It would be wise to have a Catholic servant there. My influence would--

It is your influence which emboldened papists here. This is said loud enough for the entire room to turn its attention to Cecil and Lennox, which is what Cecil wants. Even Elizabeth turns and looks back. Lennox is red with embarrassment. Cecil and Dudley continue on. Lennox looks around and sees all eyes staring at him. Elizabeth exits the room and the crowd begins to dissolve low tones to his father--

You humiliate yourself. Without hesitation Lennox turns and slaps his son hard ac the face. Darnley reels, stunned. Lennox heads for the ex Now it is Darnley whom the remaining Courtiers are starin at.  17.

TIGHT on a young Italian Man - RIZZIO - playing the Renaissance Violin with accompaniment. He is comely, and talented musician. The chamber is still in the process of being decorated - more modest in its architecture and furnishings than what saw in Hampton Court, but still brighter and more luxurio than when we first saw the castle. The Four Marys are staring at Rizzio with admiration, eve perhaps a bit of lust. He smiles at Livingston, who looks her feet while blushing. The other Marys giggle, drawing attention from some of the NOBLES who are waiting in a li to kiss Mary’s hand. Among those passing by is MAITLAND - a high-ranking Noble diplomatic and innocuous on the surface, but a snake with He and Fleming lock eyes - an instant attraction. Moray introduces the guests to Mary as they come before h

William Maitland of Lethington, Secretary of State. Maitland turns his attention back to Mary. Kneels down an kisses her hand. Next up is KNOX - a Protestant Cleric, severely dressed w an even more severe manner. MORAY (CONT’D) John Knox, Church of Scotland. As Knox bends down to kiss Mary’s hand, Rizzio screeches bow across the strings of his renaissance violin - a comi sound. Knox turns back to Rizzio with disgust. The Four M giggle, and Mary herself cannot help but smile.
A loose string. Although this thin excuse does nothing to placate Knox. M veers things back to business--
Let us begin. The Lords sit down on chairs in a semi-circle around the throne. Once they are settled, Mary addresses them in Fre
Il est certain que beaucoup d’entre vous ne vous alliez qu’ad regret a une Reine Frangaise et Catholique. (MORE )

(We are certain many of you are ill at ease aligning yourself with a French and Catholic Queen...) Some of the other Lords look askance at each other in reaction to her speaking a non-native language.
(she abruptly switches to Scots) But your Queen is in Scotland now. She pauses, letting her use of Scots sink in. Then--

When my beloved Frangois passed to God, I could have married any number of suitors. Portugal. Denmark. Sweden. Many others. The Hapsburgs offered their sons. (beat) I declined them all. On Moray. He’d much prefer she be married off.

Just as I would not have an uncertain fate imposed upon myself, I will not impose an uncertain fate upon my subjects. (beat) They remain free to worship however they so choose, Catholic or Protestant. A look of surprise from the assembled Lords. This is not they were expecting.
Elizabeth is at the head of the table. Cecil speaks on be of his fellow Counsellors, which include Dudley and Rando
Her pronouncements mean nothing. Whom she marries speaks louder than any edict from the throne.
(to Randolph) What say’st our Ambassador?
She feigns disinterest, Madam... 19.  Green Revisions (18.10.17) 20.
Randolph - in stiff formality - concludes his report.
She is formidable, Madam. On Elizabeth - she grimaces at this assessment of her riv
Mary before her Lords, as before.  21.
Pastor, you look displeased with our tolerance? A general nervousness flutters among the Lords, not least all with Moray, but Knox is not the least bit intimidated
Any realm that is ruled by the Pope is not tolerant, Madam. It is enslaved--
Stand when I address you. Knox makes a show of standing slowly, resolutely and sayi the following words with equally slow resolve.
There is one true God. And therefore one true religion.
Such rhetoric incites revolt.

If a Prince strays from God’s will, it is not in doubt that they may be resisted. And in your case, as with all women: their sight is but blindness; their strength, weakness; their counsel, foolishness; their judgment, frenzy. Are we to abide a papist and a woman both? Mary is stunned, but gathers herself to have the last, if shaky, word--
Well then, I perceive that my subjects shall obey you, and not me. And shall do what they like, and not what I command. And so must I be subject to them, and not they to me. Unwavering, and unmoved--
May I sit, Madam?
No. You may remove yourself from this council and my court. A gasp of unease from the other Lords. Knox, with all the pride he can muster--  22.
My council is among the faithful disciples I serve. We have as little need of this court as it has of us. I pray for your soul, Madam. Knox slowly makes for the door, milking his exit.
Mary walks briskly with Moray. She can no longer contain rage - face flushed, speaking as briskly as she walks--
I beg you to reconsider. He has the trust of the people.
Did I not give deference to his faith?
Yes. But we must be delicate. Allegiance does not happen by proclama-- She stops and turns to him, her rage frothing--
And where is his delicacy? That he should speak to a monarch so? Would he challenge Elizabeth thus?
With what cause? He would welcome a Protestant Queen. Which is precisely why we must not push him into her arms. Show him love.
You are wise, brother. There are times for wisdom. And there are times for love. But there are also times for strength. She continues on. Off Moray, swallowing his frustration.

A sparse, undecorated place of worship, clearly Protestan Knox stands at a pulpit, delivering a sermon. The front r are filled with nobility, including Maitland, who is sitt in the first row, listening with great interest.  23. As the rows progress toward the back they are populated w MERCHANTS and PEASANTS. It’s a packed room, and some of t peasants are forced to stand in the rear by the open door the street. This is part religious fervor, part retributi at having been removed from court--

(with force) We have a scourge upon our land. ‘Tis worse than pestilence or famine. ‘Tis worse than the Roman pagans or Egyptian pharaohs. ‘Tis a woman with a crown who only pretends to worship Christ when in truth she kneels before the Pope. We will not bow as she does. Murmurs of approval from the congregation. Knox’s charism forcefulness picks up steam--
We do not pray to false idols. We do not take instruction from Rome. We resist those who would tempt us with indulgences. Deny those who worship luxury. Respect not those who flaunt their excesses...
The Four Marys are helping Mary undress. The room is now appointed with furniture and tapestries.
...who whore themselves to wealth and the degradations of the flesh. Mary taps Fleming’s cheek with her finger.
Alors, ici? (What about here?) The girls are laughing. Fleming blushing.
(taps Flemings’ nose) Ici? (Here?)
(through her laughter) Non. (No.) Mary puts a finger to Fleming’s lips.  24.
Il vous a embrassé ici? (Has he kissed you here?)
(sheepishly) Une fois (Once...)
The others gasp, titillated.
.--Sans aller plus loin. (...But no further.)
(turning to Beaton) Et vous alors? Ils embrassent comment, les Anglais? (What about you? How well do the English kiss?)
(smiling, embarrassed) Madame... Mary turns on a dime, suddenly serious.
What matters have you discussed with the Ambassador between your kisses? A chill between them all. The undressing has halted.
Méme s’il y a de l’amitié entre lui et moi-- (We are friendly, but I--)
(to Fleming) Or you - with my Secretary of State.
Madame - vous savez que nous-- (Madam - you know we--)
In Scots.
Our loyalty is to you alone. Mary warms, thawing the chill--  25.
I jest. I know you love me. But was she jesting? They resume undressing her.
Just be wary of these men. Their love is not the same as their respect. The Mary’s remove layer upon layer, down to her smock. Af several beats--
Might I ask - since we have not known it ourselves... (gathers the courage) What is it like...? Less ashamed to complete the question than Fleming to ask

To have a man? INT. HAMPTON COURT - QUEEN’S CHAMBER - NIGHT Atop the bed with drapes drawn for privacy. Elizabeth wit Dudley. Her sleeves have been removed. The farthingale beneath her dress bulges up as they sit side by side. Dudley gently pushes the smock sleeve up Elizabeth’s fore revealing the skin of her wrist. He brings it to his mout and kisses the underside. Elizabeth closes her eyes, shak from the touch. Lips on skin is forbidden and thrilling.
I have only lain with Frangois... INT. HOLYROOD - QUEEN’S CHAMBER - NIGHT Mary with the Marys. They’re still undressing her--
He shook terribly from fright. As did I. The poor boy did his best...
MUSIC rises from a DANCE. Two hands, palms flat to each o - a man and woman's...
.--but it was over before it began.  26. BACK TO Mary in her bedchamber with the Marys--
So you never...
No. We tried but once. BACK TO the Banquet Hall - TIGHT on Mary’s glowing face, flushed from the thrill of a man’s touch--
Yet I found myself...stirred, a wanting like none other... We PULL BACK to see that she’s dancing with Bothwell--
Not so much for him... Then gliding to another Nobleman, then another, her face warmed by the music and hundreds of candles that fill the room. As she whisks between the men--

..-but for the thing itself...the touch...skin upon skin. INT. HAMPTON COURT - QUEEN’S CHAMBER - NIGHT The MUSIC from the DANCE continues as-- Dudley is kissing Elizabeth’s nape, beginning to unloosen corset, but Elizabeth pulls away. Dudley reluctantly lets go of the strings. Takes Elizabet hand and brings it between his legs.
Do you feel my passion?
